Award.AwardTitle: GSE/RES A Multi-Method Investigation of the Situational Cues and Contexts Inhibiting Women in STEM Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: This project draws on the contextual theory of social identity threat to 1) examine how the features and structures of STEM settings serve as cues to women about how they might be valued and treated in STEM settings, and 2) investigate the mechanisms by which situational cues influence women's interests, aspirations, persistence, and performance in STEM.

The proposed project involves 2 phases. Phase 1 consists of a 3-year longitudinal and experience-sampling study of women and men in 3 theoretically informative college contexts: (a) a large, public university (University of Illinois, Chicago), (b) a women?s college (Mills College), and (c) a polytechnic university (California State Polytechnic University). With the public university serving as an ecologically-valid comparison group, the researchers will investigate several situational cues (e.g., numerical representation, gender of professors, explicit institutional values of women and/or STEM, etc.) to identify the ones that most impact women's STEM outcomes. This work assesses critical time periods in students' college careers (years 1-3) when they appraise the cues in their new environments, decide upon a major, take major-related courses, and select career options. The data are analyzed using HLM techniques.

Phase 2 consists of six experimental laboratory studies that investigate the causal mechanisms by which cues affect women's STEM outcomes. In particular, they test whether the orientations that academic institutions adopt towards STEM abilities and learning moderate the extent to which situational cues affect women's STEM outcomes. Two sets of institutional orientations, drawn from the literature, are investigated: (a) fixed v. malleable lay-theories of STEM ability, and (b) competitive v. cooperative orientations. Because STEM settings are complex and likely to contain more than one situational cue, the experiments will investigate these orientations within the context of other cues known to negatively affect women in STEM (e.g., numerical under-representation, gender-segregation, and the congruence between an individual's and an institution's orientation). It is hypothesized that institutional orientations that facilitate effort and persistence while guarding against performance concerns--namely malleable (v. fixed) theories of STEM abilities and a cooperative (v. competitive) environment--will ameliorate the negative effects of under-representation and gender segregation on women's STEM outcomes. Data are analyzed using ANOVA and linear regression techniques that allow for tests of causal mechanisms.

BROADER IMPACTS: The project offers direct examinations of how situational cues influence women's interests, aspirations, persistence, and performance in STEM. This work has potential to illuminate aspects of STEM settings that negatively influence women's STEM outcomes and provide specific, concrete, and easily adaptable strategies that can be used in STEM classrooms and to train STEM faculty and students. By providing strategies for both institutions and individuals, this work is poised to provide insight into how equitable and inviting STEM environments can be created. The findings will be actively disseminated in psychology and education journals and at national conferences. A website will also be developed to enable broader dissemination. In addition, the findings will be actively shared with STEM educators at both the high school and university levels. The project fosters the integration of research and education as undergraduate and graduate research assistants are involved at every stage. Women and members of underrepresented groups will be recruited as undergraduate and graduate research assistants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes: Intellectual Merit.

The goals of our research project were two-fold. First, our aim was to longitudinally investigate the mechanisms by which cues and contingencies within existing STEM environments affected men and women's STEM outcomes at 3 very different college settings that are each theoretically informative, over a period of 4 years. Our goal was to compare women's experiences of situational cues and their downstream effects in STEM (and non-STEM) settings at 1) a large, public university, 2) a women's college, in which women's potential and leadership are explicitly valued and affirmed, and 3) a university that expressly values and prioritizes STEM education. Our theory-based model predicted that threatening situational cues would increase women's social identity concerns, increase negative affect, deplete their cognitive resources, and depress their sense of belonging. These factors would then, in turn, lead to decreases in women's interests, aspirations, persistence, and performance in STEM settings.

Overall, we found that organizations and environments that signal a fixed mindset have disparate impact on women in STEM. While numeric underrepresentation in STEM classes triggered more identity concerns among women, which in turn, depressed women’s sense of belonging and affected the goals that women set for themselves in STEM fields, the beliefs that students perceived their STEM professors to endorse about science and math abilities (i.e., professors’ mindsets) influenced women’s outcomes even more. Perceiving that a STEM professor endorsed a fixed mindset had a disparate impact on women’s motivational and academic outcomes. When women perceived that their STEM professors endorsed fixed ability beliefs, they reported more identity concerns, less belonging, more negative affect, and more cognitive depletion in those specific classes than did men. Men did not experience similar downstream effects, nor did women enrolled in classes with fixed mindset non-STEM professors. Thus it seems that perceiving STEM professors to endorse fixed mindsets are particularly deleterious for women’s outcomes in STEM. These results were confirmed through several controlled experiments.

These results are important as they suggest strategies and practices to minimize identity threat in STEM environments and preserve women’s motivation, persistence and performance. By communicating a growth mindset in these STEM environments, teachers and faculty may be able to assuage concerns about stereotyping and identity threat, and support the motivation of women and girls in STEM. This should increase the number of girls and women who enter and persist in the STEM pipeline and professions.

Project Results: Broader Impacts

The results of the project have had broad impact. The results have been widely disseminated both inside and outside academia, to communities of practice, policymakers, and students. Besides publication in several academic outlets and broader-access outlets (specifically targeting teachers and faculty), our work has been featured in major media outlets as well as in talks and workshops that the PI, co-PIs, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholar have given nationally. The results of the project, publications, and practitioner resources are available on the PI’s website. We have seen our work being picked up by scholars across many disciplines (e.g., Education, STEM education, Philosophy, Economics, Political Science) as well as by teachers and educators on the ground who are aiming to implement our findings in their classrooms.
